Award.AwardTitle: Outcome Predictions of Students in Massive Open Online Courses (OPSMOOC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This exploratory project seeks to develop methods to evaluate Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) offerings. Designed specifically for interactive study over the web, with considerable flexibility in terms of students' time commitment and scheduling, MOOCs have tremendous potential for improving access to higher education. To date, however, MOOCs have tended to exhibit high attrition rates. With enrollments in the tens or hundreds of thousands, even modest changes that increase completion rates could have a major impact on the absolute numbers of students benefiting from this new form of instruction. This project involves in-depth examination of a highly popular Harvard MOOC, offered through the edX platform. It combines primary data (on participating students' characteristics and their motivations for taking the course) with data pertaining to students' course activities in analyses (including descriptive statistics, hazard modeling, and multiple linear regression) to explore both traditional course outcomes (e.g., measures of student achievement) and persistence/attrition. By focusing on the metric of course completion early in the development of MOOCs, this project has potential to direct attention to those aspects of MOOCs that appear critical to student success and their continuing interest in STEM fields. It is anticipated that both research findings and methods of analyses can be incorporated into the instructional platform to aid instructors in monitoring difficulties and in rapid course improvement and that progress toward more uniform data collection will allow comparisons across a variety of MOOCs, particularly those with similar goals or content domains.

Institution.Name: Harvard University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs), which are college courses offered online to the general public and which are typically available for free and do not offer college credits, have recently sprung up and experienced a dramatic proliferation at elite U.S. universities. MOOCs boast huge enrollments, but seemingly few graduates--a vastly different situation from conventionally taught courses. Relatively little is known about the reasons students do not finish MOOCs. The goal of this project was to model attrition in a MOOC and identify factors that positively or negatively influence students' persistence in a MOOC.

The data came from the Harvard University MOOC SPU30x Super-Earths And Life, which was produced by HarvardX, a member of the EdX MOOC consortium of prestigious institutions of higher education.

The key findings include:

1. A relatively large percentage by MOOC standards, 23%, of registrants completed the MOOC (this percentage would, of course, vary with different definitions of participation and completion).

 

2. Participants took a variety of paths through the MOOC (not only the linear path designated by the MOOC sequence). Around 40% of the participants deviated from the designated sequence.

 

3. Of the tested predictors of student dropout in survival models, the project found:

3.a. Predictors that made no difference:

Students’ gender.

Parents' educational level.

3.b. Predictors that made a difference throughout the MOOC:

Younger students had higher dropout rates throughout.

Students from inside the U.S had higher dropout rates throughout.

Students with lower English skills had higher dropout rates throughout.

Students with a stronger motivation to earn a certificate had lower dropout rates throughout.

Students with a stronger intention to complete had lower dropout rates throughout.

Students with higher familiarity with the subject had lower dropout rates throughout.

Students with greater experience in completing prior MOOCs had lower dropout rates throughout.

Students with a higher score in the previous problem set had lower dropout rates throughout.

3.c. Predictors that made a difference at the beginning of the MOOC, but then attenuated:

Students with a higher score in the pretest had lower dropout rates than those with a lower score initially, but not in the later parts of the MOOC.

Students with a higher motivation to participate in an online community had higher dropout rates than those with a lower motivation initially, but not in the later parts of the MOOC.

Students with a higher amount of time spent in the MOOC at the previous milestone had lower dropout rates than those having spent less time initially, but not in the later parts of the MOOC.


Last Modified: 11/30/2017
Modified by: Philip M Sadler

The link between nodes represent the transitional pathways and widths of the links are proportional to the amount of participants taking pathways.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs), which are college courses offered online to the general public and which are typically available for free and do not offer college credits, have recently sprung up and experienced a dramatic proliferation at elite U.S. universities. MOOCs boast huge enrollments, but seemingly few graduates--a vastly different situation from conventionally taught courses. Relatively little is known about the reasons students do not finish MOOCs. The goal of this project was to model attrition in a MOOC and identify factors that positively or negatively influence students' persistence in a MOOC. The data came from the Harvard University MOOC SPU30x Super-Earths And Life, which was produced by HarvardX, a member of the EdX MOOC consortium of prestigious institutions of higher education. The key findings include: 1. A relatively large percentage by MOOC standards, 23%, of registrants completed the MOOC (this percentage would, of course, vary with different definitions of participation and completion). 2. Participants took a variety of paths through the MOOC (not only the linear path designated by the MOOC sequence). Around 40% of the participants deviated from the designated sequence. 3. Of the tested predictors of student dropout in survival models, the project found: 3.a. Predictors that made no difference: Students? gender. Parents' educational level. 3.b. Predictors that made a difference throughout the MOOC: Younger students had higher dropout rates throughout. Students from inside the U.S had higher dropout rates throughout. Students with lower English skills had higher dropout rates throughout. Students with a stronger motivation to earn a certificate had lower dropout rates throughout. Students with a stronger intention to complete had lower dropout rates throughout. Students with higher familiarity with the subject had lower dropout rates throughout. Students with greater experience in completing prior MOOCs had lower dropout rates throughout. Students with a higher score in the previous problem set had lower dropout rates throughout. 3.c. Predictors that made a difference at the beginning of the MOOC, but then attenuated: Students with a higher score in the pretest had lower dropout rates than those with a lower score initially, but not in the later parts of the MOOC. Students with a higher motivation to participate in an online community had higher dropout rates than those with a lower motivation initially, but not in the later parts of the MOOC. Students with a higher amount of time spent in the MOOC at the previous milestone had lower dropout rates than those having spent less time initially, but not in the later parts of the MOOC.
